Democrats try to go it alone, again
By KATHERINE TULLY-MCMANUS
01/18/2022 07:44 AM EST
Presented by
With help from Andrew Desiderio
HERE (DEMS) GO AGAIN ON (THEIR) OWN — The Senate returns today, on what was slated to be a recess week, to take action on the Democrats’ efforts to enact federal elections reform and restore key oversight protections from the Voting Rights Act, a move that is sure to lead to a showdown over the chamber’s 60-vote filibuster threshold.

But they’re also starting to ding their own leaders for overpromising and underdelivering.” Don’t miss their analysis of what another bruising week could mean for Democrats: Dems stare down another failure to deliver for their base
“If we do not protect the vote with everything that we’ve got, we will not have a country to protect going forward.

“In fact, we told Zelenskyy and others that we were in Kyiv today in part to make sure there wasn’t a false impression given by a vote on a very narrow sanction.”
And yet… last week’s vote was thorny in particular because it pitted Democrats against the Zelenskyy administration, which wanted to see Sen. Ted Cruz’s (R-Texas) bill pass.

Democrats in both chambers are struggling to frame what seems to their base like a repeat of the struggles they faced with the $1.7 trillion party-line social spending plan: pitting Democrats against each other instead of a unified message and enough votes to pass legislation backed by their base.

But their message of unity came just a few days after the Senate took a very divisive vote on sanctions for the Nord Stream 2 pipeline, which laid bare the disagreements between the two parties over how to preserve the U.S. and Ukraine’s leverage to deter a Russian incursion.

Schumer has said he’s open to “reasonable additions and modifications” to that legislation, which Menendez has dubbed “the mother of all sanctions.” Some Republicans have expressed support for the bill, which would impose unprecedented sanctions to cripple Russia’s economy.

Attn: Interns…The House’s Office of Diversity and Inclusion is hosting a resume review session Jan. 31 at 12 p.m. Staff assistants from both sides of the aisle will hold a Q&A with interns and offer tips for tailoring resumes for applications to House offices.

Senate Democrats will gather in-person tonight for a special caucus meeting ahead of this week’s risky action for the caucus, which still is not unified on altering the chamber’s filibuster rules in order to pass the elections and voting rights legislation.

It is still not clear what form that will take – there are not enough votes for eliminating the filibuster outright – but multiple options for tweaking the process have been on the table in recent weeks
All eyes, once again, will be on Sens.

“Some Republicans are mulling ways to collaborate with Biden on issues like trade, energy or tech; others are prepared to go scorched-earth as their party eyes the bigger prize of retaking the White House in 2024,” write Olivia and Burgess.

GOP SPLIT SCREEN — Republicans in both chambers are brimming with confidence that they’ll control Congress after the midterm elections, which has them thinking ahead about how to work with — or against — President Joe Biden.

Given how differently Republicans in each chamber tend to handle critical pieces of legislation like funding the government and raising the debt ceiling, the GOP’s collaborative camp could struggle in 2023.
WEEKEND IN KYIV — A bipartisan group of senators spent about 24 hours in Ukraine this past weekend to reaffirm the U.S. commitment to Ukraine’s security as it stares down a possible Russian invasion.
Calling from the Ukrainian capital, Sen. Chris Murphy (D-Conn.) downplayed and dismissed that vote as “small differences over tactics” that didn’t undermine the CODEL’s message of bipartisan unity.
Murphy said he came away from this trip believing the Senate could muster 60 votes on a conditional sanctions package, like the one offered by Senate Foreign Relations Chair Bob Menendez (D-N.J.).
